text: The Firefox logo is not a fox. It's a Red Panda, which is also called a "Firefox."
The first computer mouse, invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964, was made of wood.
The word "robot" comes from the Czech word "robota," which means "forced labor" or "drudgery."
The original name for Windows was "Interface Manager." Bill Gates was convinced to change it.
A group of scientists at Cambridge invented the first webcam in 1991 to monitor a coffee pot so they wouldn't waste a trip if it was empty.
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of the mathematical term "googol" (10^100).
Email was invented in 1971, which predates the World Wide Web (invented in 1989/1990).
The sound you hear when the original Xbox boots up contains snippets from actual NASA space missions.
Nokia started as a paper mill, then made rubber boots, tires, and toilet paper before getting into electronics.
The CAPS LOCK key is the most universally hated button in IT.
The first 1GB hard drive in 1980 was the size of a refrigerator, weighed over 500 pounds, and cost $40,000.
Your average keyboard contains 400 times more bacteria than a toilet seat. (Go clean your keyboard!)
The reason we call unrequested electronic messages "Spam" is due to a Monty Python sketch where a group of Vikings sing the word repeatedly.
Every iPhone advertisement is set to the time 9:41 AM, the exact time Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone in 2007.
Mark Zuckerberg is red-green colorblind, which is why blue dominates the Facebook color scheme.
The longest word you can type using only the top row of a QWERTY keyboard is "Typewriter."
The first commercial hard drive, the IBM 350 Disk File (1956), stored just 5 megabytes (MB) of data.
The Internet is not the same as the World Wide Web; the Internet is the physical network, and the Web is the collection of pages and links (like an ocean vs. the ships on it).
The world's first programmer was a woman named Ada Lovelace in the mid-1800s.
Domain name registration was free until 1995.
NASA’s internal network runs at speeds 13,000 times faster than the average home internet connection.
Google rents out goats to "mow" the lawns at their Mountain View headquarters.
The world’s first-ever computer was the ENIAC, built in 1945, which weighed 27 tons and took up 1,800 square feet.
Typing "askew" into a Google search bar will tilt the results page.
The "@" symbol in email addresses was chosen by Ray Tomlinson because it was not common in names and would avoid confusion.
The world’s most popular password for years has consistently been "123456" or "password."
Samsung started in 1938 as a grocery store and noodle-making business.
When using a computer, the average person blinks only 7 times per minute, compared to the normal rate of 20.
The total weight of the entire Internet (the electrons in motion that make it work) has been estimated to be roughly the weight of a single strawberry (about 50 grams).
The first video uploaded to YouTube was titled "Me at the Zoo" on April 23, 2005.
The first item sold on eBay was a broken laser pointer for $14.83. The buyer was a collector of broken laser pointers.
The concept of a computer came long before electricity: Charles Babbage designed the mechanical Analytical Engine in the 1830s.
Nintendo was founded in 1889, selling playing cards (Hanafuda).
The first computer virus, called "Creeper" (1971), was harmless and only displayed the message: "I'M THE CREEPER: CATCH ME IF YOU CAN."
"Voice.com" is one of the most expensive domain names ever sold, going for $30 million in 2019.
There are currently more connected devices (computers, phones, IoT gadgets) on Earth than there are people.
A 75-year-old woman in Georgia once accidentally severed a fiber optic cable while scavenging for copper, cutting off internet to all of Armenia and parts of Georgia for hours.
The founders of the biggest tech companies often have no college degree (Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, Mark Zuckerberg).
Ctrl+Alt+Del was originally intended to be a user-friendly feature by David Bradley, not a system-reset command.
The first digital camera (1975) was the size of a toaster, took 23 seconds to record a photo, and the image was in black and white at 0.01 megapixels.
The iconic Twitter bird logo is named "Larry," after basketball legend Larry Bird.
The Bluetooth logo is a combination of two Norse runes: H (for Harald) and B (for Bluetooth), representing Harald Bluetooth, a Danish king.
The first version of the Dwarf Fortress game was written in the programming language BASIC.
The average life expectancy of a floppy disk is 3 to 5 years.
MySpace accidentally deleted almost all music and photos uploaded to the site between 2003 and 2015 during a server migration.
The first cell phone was a Motorola DynaTAC 8000x (1983). It weighed two pounds and cost nearly $4,000.
The term "Firewall" comes from the physical barriers used to prevent a fire from spreading from one part of a building to another.
A single Google search uses more computational power than the entire Apollo 11 moon mission had available.
CAPTCHA stands for "Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart."
Only about 8% of the world's currency is physical money; the rest is stored digitally.
The biggest computer crash in history was the Y2K Bug... which was completely anticlimactic thanks to programmers working overtime.
The first online order was a CD by the band Ten Summoner's Tales in 1994.
The phrase "You've Got Mail!" was voiced by the husband of a programmer who worked on AOL.
The smallest unit of memory that can store a piece of information is a bit (binary digit: 0 or 1).
The world’s first website, created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991, is still online (info.cern.ch).
The programming language Python was named after the British comedy group Monty Python, not the snake.
The earliest known analogue computer is the Antikythera mechanism, an ancient Greek device dating back to around 100 BC.
Before founding Apple, Steve Jobs worked for Atari.
The total number of mobile devices now exceeds the world's population.
The official mascot for the BSD operating system is a smiling, waving cartoon devil named Beastie.
The original purpose of YouTube was reportedly a video dating site called "Tune In Hook Up."
In a classic tech move, when setting up his dorm room, Linus Torvalds rigged a device to detect if the lab's coffee machine was done brewing, without having to leave his desk.
The fear of computers is called logizomechanophobia.
The average computer technician's diet consists mainly of caffeine, stale donuts, and the cold dread of an upcoming Monday.
An average of 6,000 tweets are sent every second.
The number of people who fall for a phishing scam is surprisingly high because the scammers only need to be right once.
The first ever emoticon was proposed by Scott Fahlman in 1982: :-)
The original Apple logo featured Sir Isaac Newton sitting under a tree.
Amazon was originally going to be named "Cadabra" (as in Abracadabra), but the name sounded too much like "Cadaver" over the phone.
Linux was created by Linus Torvalds in 1991 as a hobby.
The first recorded public broadcast on television was in 1925 and showed a rotating puppet.
The computer game Tetris was the first video game to be exported from the Soviet Union to the US.
Most IT professionals prefer to fix problems with a single, perfectly timed reboot.
The programming language COBOL (Common Business-Oriented Language) is still used in many old banking and government systems.
The first domain registered was symbolics.com on March 15, 1985.
In 2013, over $12 million was lost in a Bitcoin scam, all due to a single spelling mistake in the code.
The computer's internal clock is often called the RTC (Real-Time Clock).
The term "algorithm" is named after the 9th-century Persian mathematician Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi.
The most popular search query on the Bing search engine is "Google."
The first person to receive a computer-generated voice message was Queen Elizabeth II in 1976.
The average lifespan of a modern computer fan is about 50,000 hours.
A Dreadnought is a type of attack that bypasses network firewalls (like the famous battleship bypassing enemy defenses).
The longest currently registered domain name is 63 characters long and belongs to a small village in Wales.
Only about 5% of the internet's content is considered "publicly indexable" by search engines; the rest is the Deep Web.
The "refresh" button on your browser is the technological equivalent of blowing on a video game cartridge.
The technology that led to Wi-Fi was originally developed by an Australian astronomer to detect exploding black holes.
The first computer game was Spacewar!, developed in 1962 by MIT students.
The most common lie in IT is, "I didn't change anything, it just stopped working!"
The first piece of music ever played by a computer was "God Save the Queen" in 1951.
A BitTorrent is named after a swarming insect, fitting its decentralized nature.
The first image uploaded to the World Wide Web was a photo of a comedy band called Les Horribles Cernettes (created by CERN employees).
The IBM 5100 (1975) was a portable computer that weighed 55 pounds.
The first-ever computer mouse only cost about $20 in parts to make.
The person who invented the GIF pronounced it with a soft 'G' (Jif), like the peanut butter.
Quantum computing uses qubits (q) which can be 0, 1, or both simultaneously (superposition).
The most difficult part of debugging is convincing yourself that the error is your fault.
The term "Trojan horse" comes from the ancient Greek story of the siege of Troy.
Bill Gates' first company, Traf-O-Data, failed.
The first advertisement for a mobile phone was printed in a magazine in 1973.
Despite all the progress in AI, you are still required to click on a tiny box to prove you are not a robot.
The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed to slow down typists to prevent mechanical jamming.
The first computer bug was an actual moth found trapped in a relay of the Harvard Mark II in 1947.
DNS (Domain Name System) is often called the 'phonebook of the Internet'.
